title: Louis, Duke of Rohan
text:
Louis de Rohan-Chabot (3 November 1652 – 17 August 1727) was a member of the House of Rohan-Chabot and <a href="Duke%20of%20Rohan">Duke of Rohan</a>. He married an heiress and acted as <a href="Louis%20XIV">Louis XIV</a>'s representative in <a href="Brittany">Brittany</a>. He was styled as the Prince of Léon prior to becoming Duke of Rohan. His direct descendant is today's <a href="Josselin%20de%20Rohan">Josselin de Rohan</a> (born 5 June 1938), a member of the <a href="Senate%20of%20France">Senate of France</a>, representing the Morbihan department.
Early life and family.
Born at the Hôtel de la rue du Temple in Paris, to Henri Chabot and his wife <a href="Marguerite%20de%20Rohan">Marguerite de Rohan</a>, Louis was the fifth of six children and their only surviving son. His parents' marriage had caused a scandal; his mother Marguerite was a <a href="Foreign%20Prince">Foreign Prince</a>ss as a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Rohan">House of Rohan</a>, and her wedding plans had caused Louis XIV to issue a decree that she was permitted to marry Henri and still hold her high rank at court.
Henri's family were allowed to bear the name of Rohan-Chabot, the hyphenation of his maternal and paternal family names.
Around 1700, Louis was at Court. The <a href="Prince%20of%20Gu%C3%A9m%C3%A9n%C3%A9">Guéméné branch</a> of the House of Rohan wanted him to abandon the name and coat-of-arms of his mother's family. However, King Louis XIV confirmed his rights to the name, title and coat-of-arms, to which his father had been entitled since 19 September 1646, part of his parents' marriage contract.
Louis was close to his older sister <a href="Anne%20de%20Rohan-Chabot">Anne de Rohan-Chabot</a>, future <a href="Princess%20of%20Soubise">Princess of Soubise</a> and mistress of <a href="Louis%20XIV">Louis XIV</a>. His youngest sister, Jeanne Pelagie, married the Prince of Epinoy, the paternal grandfather of <a href="Louis%2C%20Duke%20of%20Joyeuse%20%281694%E2%80%931724%29">Louis de Melun</a> and <a href="Anne%20Julie%20de%20Melun">Anne Julie de Melun</a>, a future Princess of Soubise. Louis' nephews included <a href="Hercule%20M%C3%A9riadec%2C%20Duke%20of%20Rohan-Rohan">Hercule Mériadec, Duke of Rohan-Rohan</a> and the <a href="Armand%20Gaston%20Maximilien%20de%20Rohan">Cardinal de Soubise</a>. Louis' godparents were the infant Louis XIV and the infant's mother <a href="Anne%20of%20Austria">Anne of Austria</a>, Queen Regent.
Career.
Louis was very rich, with an annual income of 50,000 <a href="European%20Currency%20Unit">ecus</a>, but he was a miser and greedy. His greed caused him to fall out with his sister Anne, which led to bad relations with the king himself.
Military service.
Louis campaigned in <a href="Flanders">Flanders</a> in 1667, and in the same year he became head of the nobility in Brittany and was the king's representative there. He was also involved in sieges at <a href="Tournai">Tournai</a>, <a href="Douai">Douai</a>, and <a href="Lille">Lille</a>.
Personal life.
He married Marie Élisabeth de Bec-Crespin de Grimaldi, marquise de Vardes, a granddaughter of <a href="Jacqueline%20de%20Bueil">Jacqueline de Bueil</a>, mistress of King <a href="Henri%20IV">Henri IV</a>. Louis and Marie Élisabeth were married on 18 July 1678 at the <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Saint-Cloud">Château de Saint-Cloud</a>, residence of <a href="Philippe%20I%2C%20Duke%20of%20Orl%C3%A9ans">Philippe de France, "Monsieur"</a> (brother of Louis XIV) and his wife <a href="Elizabeth%20Charlotte%20of%20the%20Palatinate">Elizabeth Charlotte of the Palatinate, "Madame"</a>.
His wife brought a considerable dowry. She was the sole heiress of her father, François René du Bec-Crespin, marquis de Vardes, comte de Moret, and Catherine Nicolaï, marquise de Goussainville. Louis and Jacqueline had 11 children, of which two sons and a daughter would go on to have progeny. Their children were:
Louis died in Paris on 17 August 1727, aged 74. He was buried at the <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Blain">Château de Blain</a>. Marie Élisabeth survived him until 27 March 1743, when she, too, died in Paris, aged 81.
